summary: Notable ASR research today includes a comprehensive analysis of the Pashto Common Voice dataset documenting its growth from 1.5 hours to 2,769 hours, and a study on enabling ASR for disordered Akan speech with a new 50-hour corpus. The DAMA framework for depth-aware model adaptation shows strong results across 18 low-resource languages with 80% fewer trainable parameters.
ideas: Depth-aware adaptation (DAMA) reveals a U-shaped adaptability pattern in speech models: early and late layers need more adaptation while intermediate layers retain shared semantics
Community-driven datasets like Common Voice show extreme contributor inequality (Gini 0.941 for Pashto), highlighting the need for diversified data collection
Disordered speech ASR remains a critical gap, with new curated corpora emerging for underrepresented languages

papers.title: From Scarcity to Scale: A Release-Level Analysis of the Pashto Common Voice Dataset
papers.abstract: Examines Pashto segment of Common Voice, documenting growth from ~1.5 hours to ~2,769 hours. Identifies challenges: extreme contributor inequality (Gini 0.941), 40% missing gender labels.

papers.title: Enabling Automatic Disordered Speech Recognition: An Impaired Speech Dataset in the Akan Language
papers.abstract: Introduces a curated corpus of Akan impaired speech containing 50.01 hours across four impairment categories: stammering, cerebral palsy, cleft palate, and stroke-induced speech disorder.

papers.title: Adapting Where It Matters: Depth-Aware Adaptation for Efficient Multilingual Speech Recognition in Low-Resource Languages
papers.abstract: Proposes DAMA framework for depth-aware model adaptation that allocates adaptation capacity by layer role, achieving results with 80% fewer trainable parameters across 18 low-resource languages.
